bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 25, 1941

div1.p: Hench desires to clear up inconsistencies in Kean's statements regarding Henry Rose Carter's service in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 25, 1941
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
August 25, 1941
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I do appreciate your kindness in perusing the long letters I've sent you and
answering them so rapidly. As I wrote Kellogg, whatever you decide as to naming the
anonymous figure should be final. You now say that Dr. Henry R. Carter was “not in
Cuba during the period of the Board's experiments (I know this from his daughter).”
But I seemed to recall that previously you told me otherwise so last night I reviewed
all our correspondence and found in your letter of Jan. 23, 1941 (page 5) your state-
ment that Carter was in charge of the quarantine service in Havana but went back to
the U. S. prior to July 23, 1900. But written on one of 2 or 3 smaller sheets which
you fastened onto your Jan. 23 letter you have written, “I find that Dr. Henry R.
Carter Public Health and Marine Hospital Service was in Havana from July 1 to Sept.
1, 1900.”should be 1899. I wonder which of these is correct. As far as the painting is concerned
I agree Carter has little place, but at your convenience I'd like to know about Carter
for my own information.

Your diary for Mar. 10, 1900 mentions the arrival of Carter. Was this Henry R.?
You mention him also on June 14. In your entry of Sept. 1 you mentioned Dr. Glennan
who succeeded Carter. In the excerpts from your diary that I have I don't find his
name later.

But the above item is not the main reason for this letter. I am holding up
the enclosed letter to Miss Wood until you have a chance to approve my sending it.
As you will see I have not sent her any of the contentious matter in Reed's letters
to you or to Sternberg. I've only sent her the excerpts as given herein. But unless
you say otherwise, I propose to let her have copies of the collection of letters which
Miss Blossom Reed let me have. Miss Wood has been trying to weeks to see Miss Reed
to borrow the complete manuscript but has been unable to get to see her or her mother.
But Miss Wood's deadline is Nov. 1 and I am disposed to assume that Miss Reed would
be as willing for Miss Wood to see the letters as for me to see them. And I assume
that Miss Wood will not quote them in extenso or use them in such a way as to lessen
their publication value for Miss Reed.

Of course, I am only sending her the letters of 1900-1901. The previous
ones from 1874 to 1900 she must get from Miss Reed and I hope she can, for they are
very revealing of his fine character.

Since starting this letter I've received already your answer to mine of yes-
terday. I think no mistake could be made with either Pinto or Ames and I leave it to
Kellogg to decide. It's his responsibility, not ours.
Please give Mrs. Kean my kindest regards.
div1.closer:
Always gratefully yours, Philip S Hench P. S. Hench, M. D.
P. S. I've written Gen. Truby another letter trying to “catch up” a bit. I did
not indicate that I had heard anything from you re my belated correspondence.
